item.title: Lawmakers Propose Measure to Avert Government Shutdown This Week
item.description: The package would also provide major new aid to Ukraine, but its fate in an initial Senate vote on Tuesday is uncertain.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Funding for the government is set to run out when a new fiscal year begins on Saturday.

item.title: White House Student Loan Forgiveness Could Cost About $400 Billion
item.description: The estimate by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office gauged the cost over 30 years, though the bulk of the effects to the economy would be felt over the next decade.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times

item.title: House Jan. 6 Panel Faces Key Decisions as It Wraps Up Work
item.description: The committee investigating what led to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol will hold its first hearing since July on Wednesday, entering the final stage of its inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Katie Benner
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Among the many unresolved issues before the House committee on Jan. 6 as it enters its final months is whether to subpoena former President Donald J. Trump to testify.

item.title: Sedition Trial of Oath Keepers to Get Underway
item.description: Jury selection begins on Tuesday in the case of Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the far-right militia group, and four other members charged with seditious conspiracy in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Susan Walsh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Stewart Rhodes plans to tell the jury that he and his subordinates believed they would be following legal orders from President Donald J. Trump on Jan. 6, 2021.

item.title: China’s Huge Appetite for Fish
item.description: Why are Chinese boats catching so many fish off the Galápagos Islands?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Isaac Haslam/Sea Shepherd, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Chinese ship fishing off the west coast of South America in July 2021.

item.title: Germany Investigates Leaks in Nord Stream Gas Pipelines
item.description: Neither of the pipelines was active, but both were filled with natural gas. The sharp drop in pressure could only be caused by a leak, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Fabrizio Bensch/Reuters
item.media:description: The land portion of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline in Lubmin, Germany, last week.

item.title: An Israel-Lebanon Border Deal Could Increase Natural Gas Supplies
item.description: Offshore gas fields in the Mediterranean could become one of several new energy sources for European countries as they seek independence from Russia.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:credit: Ariel Schalit/Associated Press
item.media:description: An Israeli naval vessel patrolling near a production platform in the Leviathan gas field in the Mediterranean Sea off Israel’s northern coast.

item.title: Strong Dollar Is Good for the US but Bad for the World
item.description: The Federal Reserve may have no choice but to wage a relentless inflation fight, but countries rich and poor are feeling the pain of plunging currencies.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: When it comes to global finance and trade, the United States has outsize influence.

item.title: NASA Smashes Into an Asteroid, Completing a Mission to Save a Future Day
item.description: The DART spacecraft completed its 10-month journey to demonstrate a technique that could defend the planet from deadly space rocks in the future.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.category: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory
item.media:credit: NASA/Johns Hopkins APL
item.media:description: The asteroid Dimorphos 11 seconds before NASA’s DART spacecraft collided with it on Monday.

item.title: How About Them Apples? Research Orchards Chart a Fruit’s Future.
item.description: Scientists working in research groves, like one in Nova Scotia, are developing your favorite new apple variety.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Landau
item.media:credit: Paul Atwood for The New York Times

item.title: Biden’s Support for Iran Protesters Comes After Bitter Lessons of 2009
item.description: President Biden has quickly backed demonstrators in Iran. When the country faced similar unrest 13 years ago, U.S. officials feared such a strong approach would be counterproductive.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Wana News Agency/Via Reuters
item.media:description: Protests in Tehran last week. The Biden administration has pushed to get satellite systems into the hands of anti-government officials in Iran.

item.title: Women in Iran Take Center Stage in Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Women have been casting off their legally required head scarves, forming the primary image of the protests. But grievances against a repressive regime go far beyond the hijab.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Women have been at the center of protests like this one last week in Tehran, defying the mandate to wear head scarves.

item.title: Fetterman-vs.-Oz Campaign Turns to a Focus on Criminal Justice
item.description: As Pennsylvania’s lieutenant governor, John Fetterman has pushed for second chances for certain convicts. But crime has become a focal point for Republicans nationwide in the 2022 elections.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Hannah Beier for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lee Horton, left, and his brother Dennis Horton in Philadelphia on Friday. They are working on John Fetterman’s campaign for Senate.

item.title: Hochul and Zeldin Turn Potential Debates Into a Game of Chicken
item.description: There may not be any debates in the New York governor’s race if Gov. Kathy Hochul and her challenger, Lee Zeldin, cannot agree on how many to hold.
item.dc:creator: Luis Ferré-Sadurní
item.media:credit: Hans Pennink/Associated Press; Justin Lane/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Gov. Kathy Hochul has agreed to one debate against her Republican rival, Lee Zeldin, but he has accepted invitations to two different debates.

item.title: Russians Are Terrified, and Have Nowhere to Turn
item.description: For citizens who want to escape conscription, there simply aren’t many options.
item.dc:creator: Ilia Krasilshchik
item.media:credit: Arkady Budnitsky/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Conscripted Russian men attending a farewell ceremony in Bataysk, Russia, on Monday.

item.title: Jamie Raskin on The Second Amendment
item.description: It is essential to reject the myth that frustrated citizens have a right to raise arms against the government.
item.dc:creator: Jamie Raskin
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Nicole Hester/Ann Arbor News, via Associated Press

item.title: Trump’s Heartless QAnon Embrace
item.description: He’s reinforcing life-ruining delusions.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen/Getty Images

item.title: Why Zombie Reaganomics Still Rules the G.O.P.
item.description: MAGA is in charge, but policy caters to the wealthy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Charles Krupa/Associated Press

item.title: Ron DeSantis Is Making an Asylum Crisis of His Own
item.description: Does America still embrace its international obligation to provide sanctuary to at least some unauthorized immigrants?
item.dc:creator: Dara Lind
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images by Xuanyu Han and Gwengoat, via Getty Images

item.title: Why Candidates Owe Voters Full Medical Transparency
item.description: Health doesn’t have to be so political.
item.dc:creator: Lawrence K. Altman
item.media:credit: Kriston Jae Bethel/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Lt. Gov. John Fetterman of Pennsylvania greets supporters following a Senate campaign rally.

item.title: We Know Shockingly Little About What Makes Humanity Prosper
item.description: Patrick Collison calls for a new ‘science of progress’
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: Where Are All Our Post-Covid Patients?
item.description: Post-Covid care has become a luxury.
item.dc:creator: Daniela J. Lamas
item.media:credit: Hokyoung Kim

item.title: Why Was Pandemic Fraud So Easy?
item.description: As the coronavirus swept the United States, the government spent vast sums to help shield the economy. But billions of dollars of that aid disappeared.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Jessica Cheung, Luke Vander Ploeg, Mooj Zadie, MJ Davis Lin, John Ketchum, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop and Chris Wood

item.title: Modern Love Podcast: How to Feel Yourself
item.description: At 83, and legally blind, a woman needs help with one of her favorite pastimes: visiting the sex shop.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Are Your Patients Worried About the Polio Vaccine?
item.description: We want to hear from you.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler and Sheera Frenkel

item.title: Jails Boss Pushed for Dying Man’s Release to Limit Rikers Death Count
item.description: Louis A. Molina, New York City’s jail commissioner, told his senior staff to ensure that a dying man was “off the Department’s count.”
item.dc:creator: Jan Ransom
item.media:credit: Andrew Seng for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louis A. Molina, commissioner of the New York City Department of Corrections, at a news conference at Rikers Island after three incarcerated inmates died in June.

item.title: 4 Years After Thrilling Cave Rescue, Sleepy Park Readies for Onslaught
item.description: An unheralded national park in Thailand was the center of global attention when 12 boys were trapped in a cave there. In the wake of major movies about the rescue, the park expects a visitor surge.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:credit: Luke Duggleby for The New York Times
item.media:description: The entrance to the Tham Luang Cave in Chiang Rai province, Thailand, last month. The rescue of 12 boys and their soccer coach trapped in the cave in 2018 has since become the focus of documentary films and Hollywood blockbusters.

item.title: U.S. Suit Over Alliance of American Airlines and JetBlue Goes to Trial
item.description: The Justice Department antitrust case contends that the carriers’ cooperation in Boston and New York reduces competition.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department is seeking to nullify an alliance between JetBlue and American in the Northeast.

item.title: Dating Apps Thrive in China, but Not Just for Romance
item.description: China has cracked down on many tech companies, but has allowed dating apps that provide social connections to flourish.
item.dc:creator: Chang Che and Zixu Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Qu Tongzhou, 28, a Shanghai resident. She recently used dating apps to make friends as she went on a trip to western China.

item.title: UTI Treatment: What to Know About Supplements and Prevention
item.description: More than half of American women will have a urinary tract infection during their lives. But can supplements really stave that off?
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Know Your Uterus
item.description: Endometriosis, fibroid tumors and structural anomalies are just a few conditions that can impact uterine health.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Hobson

item.title: Postpartum Body Changes You Should Know About
item.description: From separated abs to pelvic floor issues, what to look out for after having a baby.
item.dc:creator: Anna Nowogrodzki

item.title: This Chemical Can Impair Fertility, but It’s Hard to Avoid
item.description: Hormone-disrupting phthalates can be found in everything from plastics and household goods to personal care products. Studies have shown they may be harmful to women’s reproductive systems.
item.dc:creator: Liza Gross

item.title: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome: What It Is, How to Manage It
item.description: Often misunderstood and misdiagnosed, PCOS can play havoc with your fertility. Here’s how to recognize the symptoms and take action to protect your reproductive health.
item.dc:creator: Hilda Hutcherson
item.media:credit: Michelle Mildenberg

item.title: The Magnificent Poem Jars of David Drake, Center Stage at the Met
item.description: Before the Civil War, an enslaved artisan from South Carolina created storage vessels that transcend ceramic traditions.
item.dc:creator: Roberta Smith
item.category: Hear Me Now: The Black Potters of Old Edgefield, South Carolina (Exhibit)
item.media:credit: Lila Barth for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Storage Jar,” 1858, by David Drake, combines aspects of a message in a bottle and the Liberty Bell. The inscription reads in part: “A very Large Jar which has 4 handles = / pack it full of fresh meats — then light candles.”

item.title: How to Solve Beginner Crosswords
item.description: Get started solving the Mini, Monday and Tuesday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
